Def.Name: Red Mulberry
Def.Description: Small tree that can reach 40' in height and 18" in diameter. Red mulberry has a short trunk and stout, spreading branches that form a round-topped crown.
Def.Leaves: Simple, alternate, and up to 8" long. The leaves are broad, egg-shaped, and lobed. The base of the leaf is square, as if it has been cut off abruptly. The tip of the leaf is pointed. The leaves have sharply serrated margins. The upper leaf surface is rough to the touch. The lower surface is soft and covered with short hairs. The petioles are 13/16" - 1 3/16" long and produce a milky fluid when broken.
Def.Twigs: Green to orangeish-brown, zigzags, milky sap when broken; buds, light brown, dark brown scaly margins.
Def.SeedConeOrFruit: Fruit: Multiple of drupes, 13/16" - 1 3/16" long that are juicy and have a dark purple color.
Def.Bark: The bark can be smooth or scaly and is orange to dark brown in color.
Def.Range: Hardy to Zone 4b. Mostly found in floodplains, river valleys, and moist hillsides.
Def.Remarks: Red mulberry was used by several Native American tribes to treat a variety of ailments. The sap was used to treat ringworm. The Cherokee made a tea from the leaves of the plant for treatment of dysentery, weakness, and difficulty urinating. The Comanche used the fruit of the red mulberry as a food source.
